page.background: The proliferation of single board computers has greatly reduced the cost and complexity of drone development. As a result, an exponential number of drones are taking to the skies each year, outpacing the FAA and local authorities' ability to regulate them. The difficulty of regulating aerial vehicles compounded with the ability of pilots to navigate their drones from remote locations exposes a serious vulnerability with maintaining privacy, safety and security.
page.report_purpose: This report will investigate a novel way to police drones using an anti-drone system.
page.fsb.approach: The approach discussed below surveys an anti-drone that would autonomously track and capture a target drone using electromagnets.
page.key_findings: The report highlights many potential difficulties in development -- chiefly that research is being performed in tandem with engineering -- making predicting success highly difficult, however the design remains feasible enough to develop as a proof of concept.

page.app_ovr: The anti-drone will be able to takeoff from a given location while being operated by a pilot. Once the target is in frame and recognized, the drone should be capable of autonomously moving above of the target.

Once the anti-drone is in position, electromagnets will be deployed to neutralize the target. At this point the pilot can resume control and navigate the anti-drone to a position in which the disabled drone can be dropped.

The FAA has regularly been advancing their regulations on drone usage. The most up to date rules can be found at: https://www.faa.gov/uas/media/Part_107_Summary.pdf. Relevant to our project are the weight constraints (55lb), licensing requirements and flight regulations (Cannot be operated indoors, drone must be visible from pilot's location and drone cannot fly over individuals not involved in its development).

page.fsb_hlgt: This project has been allotted a budget of $1,000. Glad you included budget, it puts alot of the project in perspective Although it is possible to appeal for additional funding, there do not exist products on the market that could directly address our goals even with ample funding. It is worth noting that many equal and more advanced DIY projects have achieved success on smaller budgets.

The project can be broken down into four stages. 1) Determine necessary equipment to assemble a quad-copter drone and camera configuration. 2) Enable long range object tracking for stationary targets. 3) Develop and attach the magnet capturing system. 4) Accommodate short range object tracking and automated capturing for stationary targets. 5) Develop tracking and capture of moving targets.
1) In order to allow for ample time to tackle the advances in research put forth by our project, it is vital to minimize the amount of time dedicated to drone construction. As a result a quad-copter style frame makes more sense than investing in the more difficult to control (although more steady) hex or octo-copter designs. By using a frame kit, time will be saved by not having to build and tune one from scratch, and being able to modify it provides obvious benefits that buying a stock-copter does not. Similarly, the choice of the Pixy CMUcam5 for camera allows all object detection to be automated. This not only frees up the time of the software developers, allowing them to focus on other goals, but it also justifies the use of the Raspberry Pi 3b -- which has a less complex set of barriers than its more powerful SOC counterparts.
2) The data being fed from the Pixy should allow for object identification and location. Determining motor commands in order to move toward an identified object is straightforward in a low-variable environment, however the movement of our anti-drone and the frame size of the Pixy (risking the visual loss of the target) pose significant issues. This will likely need to be accommodated by slow movements and an adjustable camera.
3) The chief concerns for the magnetic system is the weight that it would add to the drone and issues that EMI might cause. A Faraday cage might be a working alternative, however testing will need to be performed to determine the possibility of this option.
4) In order to descend upon the target, it is very likely that a second camera will need to be added facing downward. The issues with kinematics in this step are that movement must be much more fine in order to ensure visual of the target drone is not lost. Additionally the acquisition of the target must be performed in a way that does not damage the anti-drone, and does not cause an irreconcilable weight increase.
5) The processes described above are made significantly more challenging when both objects are moving. It is realistic that this would be a project in itself.
Acquiring a license and executing the above processes should be of no great impediment.

page.req_sect: Hardware Design The anti-drone must be capable of flying and be of proper tuning such that moderate gusts of wind and sudden weight gains do not cause the vehicle to malfunction. A flying time of roughly 10 minutes is to be expected.

Automated Flight The anti-drone should be capable of the anti-drone can autonomously navigate to and follow a test drone. Before deployment in the real world, a time requirement should be instantiated such that the drone could react quickly to a threat, however as this report details a research project, there is no time expectation in effect.

Drone Acquisition The anti-drone should be able to make contact with at least a 10lb target drone. Theoretically it should be able to disable the target drone, however there is no way of guaranteeing that the magnets will be capable of this in all circumstances. After acquisition, the drone should be able to fly at least 100 yards with the target drone in tow before releasing it.

The primary risks posed to this project are assessed as follows:
These risks can be mitigated as follows : Severe Crash : Maintain a low cost of components. Only of the expenditures proposed are attributed to on-board systems. Replacing these is trivial. The largest consequence of any broken components would be the downtime in development.
Connectivity Issues : Time spent solving these issues is offset by our choice of devices that are well known for easy development environments.
Unworkable EMF : Should the electromagnet not be a viable solution, other alternatives of capture can be investigated.
System Compatibility: Preliminary analysis has been performed to verify all components are compatible.
Processor Overwork : Using the Pixy to perform image analysis off of the Raspberry Pi heavily reduces the workload expected of the controls program. Time frame : Weekly assessments of development must be in place to ensure the workload keeps pace. Given our project tackles two new ares (tracking and capture) of drone technology, the goal of capture can be left incomplete without having the entire project be deemed a failure. Under-budgeting : We have received notice that an additional $200 can likely be made available to us should our project run over budget.

In order to accomplish the mission put forth by our capstone design, not only does our project require well executed engineering, but it will also contain an aspect of research. The engineering portion is represented by the leveraging of existing tools, and the research portion is represented in our tracking and capture technology. Due to the uncertainty of research, not only is it impossible to accurately predict the development process, but it also obfuscates what is realistic. The primary point of difficulty will be the limited time we have to develop our product. There is no doubt that what we seek to do is possible, however budgeting time is of the greatest order of importance. Minimizing time spent on "reinventing the wheel" will allow us to focus on the unique aspects of our project, however even then it still seems doubtful that the project will be functioning at peak performance come December. It is reasonable to expect the tracking capabilities of two moving objects can be completed by December, however the team will need to reevaluate at a later and better informed date if time allows for the capturing capabilities to be integrated.

report.p: Oliver is writing a feasibility study for developing an anti-drone system in order to combat the speedy rise of commercial drones because of the percieved risks to safety and security, and also the slowness of regulation to adapt to technology.

So firstly, I have to hand it to the author and say that this is a really cool idea. His preliminary document mentioned that he has worked with this as part of his capstone, and I think it lends itself really well to the genre of the Feasibility Study. He mentioned that he wanted to avoid being redundant in the document, I definitely understand that because it is easy to do so here. Oliver does a really good job avoiding this and it makes the document fun to read, which feasibility studies are often not. I noted a few things I thought were discrepancies in the table of contents, but otherwise the present content matches the genre very well, at least from my understanding of it.

That being said I think this specific feasibility study would benefit greatly from a risk analysis chart and an image/design of the proposed system. I think detailing what you believe the final result may look like, even if you don't have the full picture yet, would help support the "pick-up and read" idea of feasibility studies. It would support the simplicity of the document, and as you know everyone loves pictures.

Oliver asked for a critique of his use of "pre_req_ana and succ_crit", but I think they are being used very appropriately. I think he avoids being redundant where it is very easy to do and successfully separated the paradigm of thinking between the two. The "What will we have to do" vs "what will make / break this project" My one thought might be to include more regulatory thoughts relating to the permitting of the anti-drone device and how you might run into legal trouble, but that could also be included in a risk analysis table.
